title: Adults: Don’t Make Greta Thunberg Do Your Job
text:
Sixteen-year-old climate-change activist Greta Thunberg delivered a furious, now much-shared speech to the United Nations Climate Action Summit on Monday. In it she articulated the discomfort I and many other adults have felt about all of the adoration that swirls around her. “This is all wrong,” Thunberg said, seeming to bite back tears. “I shouldn’t be up here. I should be back in school on the other side of the ocean. Yet you all come to us young people for hope. How dare you! You have stolen my dreams and my childhood with your empty words.”

Indeed how dare adults hold up a child as inspiration for how to confront inaction on climate change (or for that matter gun violence) when that is their—our—job? How dare they venerate her with “Yas, little queen!” and props for “schooling the adults” when her very existence as a young leader is a sign that the adults have failed at the basic duty of protecting the children of their society? Yes, Thunberg is an exceptional activist, but she shouldn’t have to be. She and other children should not have to rise up, march in the streets, and assume the responsibility of fighting for their lives.

Perhaps the only thing worse than grown men and women declaring that they want to be Greta when they grow up is the impulse by some adults to fire back at her as if she were their equal. President Trump—lest we forget, a father of five—chose to troll Thunberg on Twitter in another banner moment, as noted by journalist Jennifer Mendelsohn, for the first lady’s Be Best campaign.

Because bashing children is her brand, Fox News host Laura Ingraham—whose greatest hits include mocking Parkland survivor David Hogg for his college rejections (and losing advertisers over it)—likened Thunberg to Children of the Corn on her show on Monday night. This drew the ire of, one, anyone with a conscience and, two, Ingraham’s own brother, who condemned her comments on Twitter.

But naturally, that wasn’t the only time Thunberg was lambasted on Fox News. In yet another instance of adults attacking a child for making the outrageous request of a safe planet to live upon, Michael Knowles (a conservative pundit whose radio show includes a recent episode titled “They’re Turning the Frickin’ Penguins Gay”) called Thunberg, who was diagnosed with Asperger’s syndrome, “a mentally ill Swedish child.” The first words from progressive pundit Christopher Hahn’s mouth were borrowed from Thunberg: “How dare you.”

Fox News saw fit to issue an apology—which should be noteworthy in itself—saying in a statement: “The comment made by Michael Knowles who was a guest on The Story tonight was disgraceful—we apologize to Greta Thunberg and to our viewers.” But of course, for better or worse, the most apt response came from Thunberg herself:

description: Thunberg is an incredible activist, but she shouldn’t have to be. The kids are not alright when President Trump, Laura Ingraham, and conservative Fox News pundits are attacking a child.
